## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-08-31T17:47:33Z
## Message ID: 20230831-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2023-08-31T16:37Z. 
Some magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm possible. This event is under analysis. 

Activity ID: 2023-08-31T16:37:00-IPS-001.

## Notes: 
This arrival might be associated with the eruption in Active Region 13413 near disk center on 2023-08-26, for which no clear CME signatures were detected in coronagraphs at the time.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-08-31T16:26:30Z
## Message ID: 20230831-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-08-30T22:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~729 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -7/6 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-08-30T22:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2023-09-02T18:12Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-09-01T12:41Z, and STEREO A at 2023-09-02T09:34Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-09-02T13:09Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME 2023-08-30T22:12:00-CME-001):

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and minor levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares and 11 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CME would impact non-Earth locations: 

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-08-26T22:36Z   Mars at 2023-09-01T12:30Z and Lucy at 2023-09-03T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230827-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2023-09-05T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13415 (currently located at S10W30) and Active Region 13417 (currently located at S07E50) each produced an M-class flare during the reporting period and may exhibit increased flaring activity during the outlook period. As seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO, there are currently two unnumbered Active Regions visible near the eastern limb around latitudes N22 and S20 which might also exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole currently centered around N30W24 (as seen in SDO EUV imagery) crossed the central meridian on 2023-08-28 and may become geoeffective on or around 2023-08-31. Additional coronal hole structures currently visible in SDO EUV imagery around N43E20 and S40E35 may develop further and become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Lucy, Mars)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-08-27T15:59:56Z
## Message ID: 20230827-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-08-26T22:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~734 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 48 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -100/-10 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-08-26T22:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Lucy and Mars. The leading edge of the CME may reach Lucy at about 2023-09-03T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) and will reach Mars at 2023-09-01T12:30Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2023-08-26T22:36:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2023-08-26T22:36:00-CME-001) is associated with an M1.1 flare with ID 2023-08-26T22:05:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2023-08-26T22:50Z, located on or just beyond the east limb at an apparent latitude of about S05 as seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery.

This CME is measured with an approximated longitude due to a lack of stereoscopic viewpoints. Longitude is +/- 20 degrees.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 16, 2023 - August 22, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-08-23T21:26:50Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-08-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230823-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and minor levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare and 9 C-type CMEs (see details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-18T19:48Z and the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-18T22:00Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-08-22T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 1-2 (below minor) (see notification 20230819-AL-001). The arrival of these CMEs have not been detected at L1. 

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-08-22T23:29Z associated with the M1.1 flare from AR13405 (N09W28) may reach NASA missions near Earth at 2023-08-26T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20230823-AL-001).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:  

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-08-17T02:48Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-08-19T07:08Z (see notification 20230817-AL-001)
2023-08-17T12:48Z   Juno at 2023-09-03T02:30Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230818-AL-001)
2023-08-17T17:36Z   Juno at 2023-09-03T02:30Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230818-AL-001)
2023-08-18T19:48Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-22T22:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-21T08:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2023-08-22T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230819-AL-001)
2023-08-18T22:00Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-22T22:00Z (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-21T08:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2023-08-22T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230819-AL-001)
2023-08-22T23:29Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-26T06:30Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-24T22:41Z, and STEREO A at 2023-08-25T19:46Z (see notification 20230823-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.33 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. Electron flux levels were elevated above background levels at the beginning of the reporting period on 2023-08-16 as a radiation belt enhancement observed from the prior reporting period since 2023-08-11T13:05Z continued to subside (see notifications 20230811-AL-002, 20230813-AL-001, and 20230815-AL-001). A minor enhancement above background levels was also observed towards the end of the reporting period on 2023-08-21 and 2023-08-22.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were at near-background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been relatively low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-08-29T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are several active regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13405 (N09W41), which recently produced an M1.1 flare on 2023-08-22, may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity during the beginning of the outlook period. Additional flaring activity may be seen from recently numbered Active Regions 13413 (N09E52) and 13415 (S09E66) as they traverse the Earth-facing disk.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Increased geomagnetic activity may be observed around 2023-08-26 in association with the predicted arrival of a C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-08-22T23:29Z (see notification 20230823-AL-001). Additionally, a small coronal hole currently visible near the central meridian of the Earth-facing disk near latitude S08 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2023-08-27.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-08-22T23:29Z.

Estimated speed: ~679 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 14/-7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-08-22T23:29:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, and STEREO A. The leading edge of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-26T06:30Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-24T22:41Z, and STEREO A at 2023-08-25T19:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-08-26T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230823_040400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20230823_040400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif


## Notes: This simulation may represent an overestimate of potential impacts at NASA missions as the CME observed in coronagraph imagery was comparatively faint. Analysis and modeling of this event is very uncertain across all parameters including velocity, width, and source location, given the current geometry of the available observing spacecraft, broad area of the solar disk over which the eruption occurred, existing data gaps, and faintness of the CME.

This CME event (2023-08-22T23:29:00-CME-001) is likely associated with M1.1 flare with ID 2023-08-22T22:35:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2023-08-22T23:04Z.

## Summary:
 
Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by SOHO. 
 
Start time of the event: 2023-08-18T19:48Z.
 
Estimated speed: ~505 km/s.
 
Estimated opening half-angle: 31 deg.
 
Direction (lon./lat.): 41/21 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.
 
Activity ID: 2023-08-18T19:48:00-CME-001
 
2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 
 
Start time of the event: 2023-08-18T22:00Z.
 
Estimated speed: ~540 km/s.
 
Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.
 
Direction (lon./lat.): 42/24 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.
 
Activity ID: 2023-08-18T22:00:00-CME-001
 
Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow), Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The combined flank of the CMEs will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-22T22:00Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-21T08:00Z, and STEREO A at 2023-08-22T08:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CMEs may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the combined flank of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-08-22T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 1-2 (below minor).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period with 10 C-type CMEs and 1 O-type CME (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:  

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-08-09T16:12Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-08-11T15:42Z (see notification 20230809-AL-004)
2023-08-09T16:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-08-11T15:42Z (see notification 20230809-AL-004)
2023-08-10T02:48Z   Juno at 2023-08-28T00:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-08-10T16:00Z   Mars at 2023-08-16T06:45Z 
2023-08-11T06:36Z   Mars at 2023-08-17T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230811-AL-001)
2023-08-14T20:48Z   Mars at 2023-08-21T03:00Z (glancing blow)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.00 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt initially crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-08-09T15:20Z and has remained elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20230809-AL-002 and 20230809-AL-003). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of the C-type CME which was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 during the previous reporting period at 2023-08-02T09:12Z. The combined arrival of the CMEs detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-08-07T11:07Z may have further enhanced the electron fluxes during this reporting period (see notifications 20230811-AL-002, 20230813-AL-001, and 20230815-AL-001).

A solar energetic particle event previously observed by SOHO on 2023-08-07 and by GOES and STEREO A on 2023-08-08 persisted through the beginning of the reporting period. At SOHO, one or more of the >15.8 MeV channels were above the 10^1 pfu/MeV threshold, subsiding below 10^-1 pfu/MeV on 2023-08-10 (see notification 20230807-AL-005). At GOES, the energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons was above the 10 pfu threshold, subsiding below 10 pfu on 2023-08-10 (see notifications 20230808-AL-002 and 20230808-AL-003). At STEREO A, the 13-100 MeV protons were above the 10^-1 pfu/MeV threshold, subsiding below 10^-1 pfu/MeV on 2023-08-10 (see notifications 20230808-AL-004, 20230808-AL-005, and 20230809-AL-001). During the remainder of the reporting period, the particle environment gradually returned to background levels at all locations.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A, and the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-16T00:00Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13405 (N10E55) produced many C-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to produce flaring activity during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Coronal hole structures currently visible on the Earth-facing disk around N35W50 and S15W40 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may become geoeffective during the beginning of the outlook period between 2023-08-16 to 2023-08-18. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

Two solar energetic particle events were detected during the reporting period. The first solar energetic particle event was detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES. At STEREO A, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-08-05T10:00Z (see notifications 20230805-AL-002 and 20230805-AL-006). At SOHO, the flux of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-08-05T10:19Z and the flux of the 28.2-50.1 protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV at 2023-08-05T10:47Z (see notification 20230805-AL-006). At GOES, the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-08-05T11:15Z (see notifications 20230805-AL-003 and 20230805-AL-006). This solar energetic particle event was associated with an M1.6 flare which peaked at 2023-08-05T07:20Z and subsequent O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-05T07:12Z and may have been further enhanced by the X1.6 class flare peaking at 2023-08-05T22:21Z and subsequent O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-05T22:24Z.

The second solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A. At SOHO, the flux of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-08-07T22:09Z and the flux of the 28.2-50.1 protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV at 2023-08-07T22:19Z (see notification 20230807-AL-005). At GOES, the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-08-08T01:00Z (see notifications 20230808-AL-002 and 20230808-AL-003). At STEREO A, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^-1 pfu/MeV at 2023-08-08T04:26Z (see notifications 20230808-AL-004 and 20230808-AL-005). This solar energetic particle event was associated with an X1.5 flare which peaked at 2023-08-07T20:46Z and subsequent O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-08-07T20:48Z.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES and STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-08-15T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels during the outlook period. The SEP event at STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES which started on 2023-08-07 is still ongoing. There are currently seven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13386 produced the majority of the M-class flares and the two X-class flares during the reporting period before rotating off the Earth-facing disk around 2023-08-07, and may continue to produce notable activity from beyond the limb. In addition, Active Region 13387 rotated off of the Earth-facing disk around 2023-08-09 and may continue to produce notable activity.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt recently crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-08-09T15:20Z and is most likely associated with the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-08-02T09:12Z that was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-08-05T02:10Z (see notifications 20230809-AL-002 and 20230809-AL-003). The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux may continue to be elevated throughout the outlook period.

### Notification information (OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)

Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact STEREO A. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

STEREO A between about 2023-08-06T17:52Z and 2023-08-07T07:49Z (average arrival 2023-08-07T02:16Z) for 95% of simulations.

Additionally the CMEs is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-08-06T21:30Z and 2023-08-07T13:36Z (average arrival 2023-08-07T06:15Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 90% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor).

## Notes: These CME events (2023-08-04T04:17:00-CME-001 and 2023-08-04T04:49:00-CME-001) are also predicted to have a glancing blow at OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-07T18:34Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-06T05:43Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20230804-AL-002). 

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 19 M-class flares, 7 C-type CMEs, 1 O-type CME, and 1 R-type CME (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-07-28T22:36Z may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-07-31T23:41Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20230729-AL-003). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 24 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-07-31T20:28Z and 2023-08-01T10:36Z (average arrival 2023-08-01T02:48Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is an 88% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-07-29_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA035/Detailed_results_20230728_223600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA035.txt (see notification 20230729-AL-006). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-08-01T10:08Z (see notification 20230801-AL-001). STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data may have also detected the arrival of this CME around 2023-08-01T06:00Z.

Additionally, it was estimated that the S-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-07-31T23:12Z, the C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-07-31T23:36Z, and another C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-08-01T00:12Z are estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth at 2023-08-04T05:27Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20230801-AL-002). Analysis of these events is currently ongoing.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-07-27T21:36Z   Mars at 2023-08-02T02:40Z and Lucy at 2023-08-04T03:35Z
2023-07-28T15:53Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-07-30T20:00Z (minor impact) and Juno at 2023-08-12T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20230728-AL-002, 20230728-AL-004 and 20230728-AL-005)
2023-07-28T22:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-07-31T03:54Z, STEREO A at 2023-07-31T19:15Z, and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-01T13:41Z (see notifications  20230729-AL-003 and 20230729-AL-006)
2023-07-29T07:53Z   Mars at 2023-08-04T14:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-07-31T23:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-03T14:36Z, STEREO A at 2023-08-04T00:01Z, and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-05T02:42Z (see notification 20230801-AL-002)
2023-08-01T00:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-03T14:36Z, STEREO A at 2023-08-04T00:01Z, and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-05T02:42Z (see notification 20230801-AL-002)
2023-08-01T12:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-08-03T16:00Z (minor impact), STEREO A at 2023-08-04T20:00Z (glancing blow), and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-08-05T16:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20230802-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-07-26T03:00Z-06:00Z. This minor enhancement of geomagnetic activity was caused by the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-07-25T21:54Z (see notification 20230726-AL-001) which was associated with the arrival of the O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2023-07-23T15:05Z (see notifications 20230723-AL-001 and 20230724-AL-003) from the previous reporting period. The arrival of this CME may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2023-07-25T19:00Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt initially crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-07-29T14:45Z and has remained elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20230729-AL-004, 20230729-AL-005, and 20230731-AL-001). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of the O-type CME mentioned above which was detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 during the previous reporting period at 2023-07-25T21:54Z.

Additionally, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A. At SOHO, the flux of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-07-28T19:19Z and the flux of the 28.2-50.1 protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-07-28T19:23Z (see notification 20230728-AL-003).  At GOES, the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-07-28T23:50Z (see notifications 20230728-AL-006 and 20230729-AL-002). Finally, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-07-29T00:53Z (see notifications 20230729-AL-001, 20230729-AL-002 and 20230730-AL-001). This solar energetic particle event was associated with an M4.1 flare which peaked at 2023-07-28T15:58Z and subsequent R-type CME first visible in STEREO A coronagraph imagery at 2023-07-28T15:53Z (see notifications 20230728-AL-002, 20230728-AL-004, and 20230728-AL-005). The particle environment has returned to background levels at all locations. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES and STEREO A, and the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-08-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-08-08T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels during the outlook period. There are currently eight numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13380 (currently located at S10W64) produced the majority of M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to produce notable activity before rotating off the Earth-facing disk around 2023-08-05. Additionally, there is at least one unnumbered Active Region visible near the eastern limb in SDO imagery located around latitude S22 which may exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Increased geomagnetic activity may be observed on or around 2023-08-04 with the anticipated arrivals of several Earth directed CMEs observed during the reporting period (as previously summarized above). Additionally, a continued enhancement in the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux is possible during the first half of the outlook period due to the recent arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO at 2023-07-28T22:36Z that was detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-08-01T10:08Z (see notification 20230801-AL-001).
